Commutative Law
A law of composition on a set $M$ is commutative if $ab = ba$ for all elements $a, b \in M$.
Polynomial

A polynomial with coefficients in a field or ring is defined as a formal sum $f=\sum_{j=0}^{n} a_{j} X^{j}$, where $a_{j}$ are the coefficients. This definition emphasizes that a polynomial is identified with the sequence of its coefficients.
Division Ring
A ring R is called a division ring or a skew field if R is not the zero ring and every nonzero element of R is a unit (R* = R - {0}).
Ring Epimorphism
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an epimorphism if it is surjective.
Irreducible element

Let $R$ be an integral domain and $p \in R$ a nonzero nonunit. $p$ is called irreducible if a factorization of type $p=x y$ with $x, y \in R$ implies $x \in R^{*}$ or $y \in R^{*}$. Furthermore, $p$ is called reducible if it is not irreducible.
Primitive Polynomial

A polynomial $f \in R[X]$ with coefficients in a unique factorization domain $R$ is called primitive if the greatest common divisor of all its coefficients is 1, or equivalently, if $
u_p(f) = 0$ for all prime elements $p \in R$.
Galois Group of a Polynomial Splitting Fields
The Galois group of a polynomial equation is the group of automorphisms of the splitting field of the polynomial that fix the base field. These automorphisms permute the roots of the polynomial.
Finite Ring Homomorphism

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is finite if $B$ is a finite $A$-module under $\varphi$. This is also referred to as $B$ being finite over $A$ or, if $\varphi$ is an inclusion homomorphism, that the extension $A \hookrightarrow B$ is finite.
Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension

The Galois group, or automorphism group, $\\[\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathbb{F}_q}(\mathbb{F}_{q'})\]$ of a finite field extension $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'} / \mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group of field automorphisms of $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'}\]$ that fix $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$. It is cyclic of order $n$, where $n$ is the degree of the extension.
Separable extension
An extension $L / K$ is called separable if it does not contain any inseparable algebraic elements over $K$.
p-group
A finite group G is called a p-group if the order of G is a power of p, where p is a prime number.
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A primitive polynomial is defined in terms of a unique factorization domain, which is a type of integral domain. Therefore, the concept of an integral domain must be defined to understand a primitive polynomial.

The Galois group of a polynomial splitting field is defined in terms of the splitting field of the polynomial, which is a field extension. Therefore, the concept of a field extension must be defined to understand the Galois group of a polynomial splitting field.

The Galois group of a finite field extension is defined in terms of field automorphisms that fix a base field. Therefore, the concept of a field extension must be defined to understand the Galois group of a finite field extension.
A polynomial is defined in terms of coefficients that belong to a field or ring. Therefore, the concept of a field or ring must be defined to understand a polynomial.
A ring epimorphism is defined as a surjective ring homomorphism. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand a ring epimorphism.
A finite ring homomorphism is defined in terms of a ring homomorphism. Therefore, the concept of a ring homomorphism must be defined to understand a finite ring homomorphism.
